Derek,

What prompts my question is an experiment which employs a local 
gr=
adient search, utilizing the organism output vector as the start 
point. Th=
e result is usually a higher fitness vector than the 
original organism out=
put vector fitness.

One interpretation is to view the implementation as a =
transform of 
the solution space (i.e. finding the best starting point whic=
h leads 
to the best fitness). Pairing the local optimal fitness to the 
or=
ganism rather than the fitness associated with the organism output 
vector.=


Another possibility is to re-write the organism genome such that the 
loc=
al optimal vector is it's new output, and assigning the local 
optimal fitn=
ess to the new substituted organism. But the problems of 
species membershi=
p and gene markers are lost.

Thus the possibility of embedding the local o=
ptimal genome as the 
recessive gene of the original organism, would allow =
the species 
membership and gene markers to remain. At least until the curr=
ent 
population has been evaluated.

Have you heard of any work involving r=
e-writing the organism genome 
during the evaluation phase?

Thanks,
Andy

=

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> Andy,
>=
 
> Not that I know of...maybe Ken knows of NEAT implementations of 
recess=
ive genes.
> 
> At one point with ANJI, we discussed going down this route.=
 Since
> genes in NEAT are traditionally monoploid (having only one set of
=
> genes), but we thought about doing a diploid representation (two 
sets
> =
of genes, one from each parent). You could then use 
dominant/recessive
> m=
arkers for genes to determine which ones are expressed. You could
> also ex=
periment with blending, for example in connection weights,
> where there is=
 neither a recessive nor dominant expression, but some
> blended function o=
f the two (e.g. an average of the two). And if you
> wanted to get really w=
eird, you could implement polyploidy, where 
each
> individual has any numb=
er of sets of genes (e.g. each individual 
could
> have 10 parents).
> 
> I=
'd be interested to see some data from a direct comparison of an
> implemen=
tation with and without recessive genes, so if you're going 
to
> do it, le=
t us know.
> 
> --Derek
>

volutionary progression, 
until

e activated, perhaps as a

preferably in the 
context
